document.text: Stuart Farrar, of Pamplin, happened upon a shelf of Lyn chburg directories among the records in the court house, Ly nchburg. In the oldest directory there, 1887-1888 he found sev eral pages of interesting in formation about this county back when  Rose Bower ,  Neb raska ,  Reedy Springs etc. were post office locations.  Ne-  braska , of course was the pre sent county seat,the Town of Appomattox. Population in 1887 was 10,080 with 5,153 white and 4,927 colored. County seat was  listed as Appomattox CH the  old village, now Appom attox j Court House National Historical j Park with a population of 100.  Average assessed value of j lands in 1887-1888 was 4.13 j per acre. The Circuit Court of I the Fifth Circuit met on the 15th  of March and 15th of Sept, with  Judge John D. Horsley and Geo rge T. Peers as clerk. Henry T. Parish was county judge and Mr. Peers serving as clerk and County Court met at the Court House Thursday after the 1st Monday in each month. County officers 84 years ago were T. B. Bryant, sheriff A.S. j Swan, surveyor, J . R. Franklin, Treasurer George W. Abbitt, commissioner of the revenue and W. C. Franklin, common wealths attorney. The supervisor board, then as now, was composed of three representatives, one from each district Wm. White was chair man together with D. H. Mar shall and H. E . Gilliam. County magistrates were A. Womack, C . H. Gilliam, Pam plin City Ja s. A. Walker, Tower Hill N. W. Owen, Oakville C. W. Cardwell, Spout Spring C.B .

document.text: sister Southern States, which had already seceded. The call went out for volunteers to defend the firesides of the Old Do minion. Appomattox County responded nobly. A Cavalry Company was formed under the command of Capt. Joel W. Flood, becoming Co. H of the 2nd Va. Cavalry. A Company of Heavy Artillery was formed under Capt. James Robertson. A Company of Infantry under Capt. Thos. P. Mat thews, and another Company was formed under Capt. Wm. H. Abbitt, and quite a number of Appomattox citizens living near the rim of the county joined companies from adjoining coun ties. With hearts aflame and bodies dedicated to the Cause they held dear, they went to the front and shared the destiny of the heroes in Gray. Weakened by casualties, new calls came for volunteers, and long after the war, there was a scarcity of able bodied men in the County. Then came April 9, 1865, and the hand of destiny wrote finis across the scroll of four mighty years of struggle Destiny selected Appomattox for one of the major events oi history. Today there is hardly a town- or village in America, that has not heard of Appomattox. Thus ended in this Coun ty, one of the greatest Civil Wars ever chronicled in the files of Time, and at Appomattox began a new page in the history of America. Military rule was established shortly after April 9, 1865. Al county officers were replaced by military appointees. These were men who were selected upon the recommendation of the incumbents, and were willing to take the Iron Clad Oath. In the fall of 1866, an election was held under the Under wood Constitution, which put into effect the 13th and 14th Amendments to the Constitution of the United States, and a new slate of officers were named. Geo. T. Peers became Clerk Wm. T. Johnson Sheriff W. J. Collins, Commissioner of the Revenue the Office of County Treasurer was created Supervisors were provided for, and the ounty Government, practically as we have it now was estab lished. The ravages of four years of war were apparent, and Ap pomattox along with her sister counties, began to repair the wounds. The following years called forth the character and ability of her people, and the present institutions of our Coun- -y are but a tribute to their untiring labor and foresight. From 1870 to the present has been a period of rebuilding and achievement. From its creation the County has been served until now by the following Officers CIRCUIT JUDGESJudges G. A. Wingfield, J. D. Hors- rv, Sam Coleman, George J. Hundley, Robt. F. Hutcheson and Joel W. Flood. COUNTY JUDGESLewis Daniel Isbell, Henry T. Par-  rish and David A. Christian. TRIAL JUSTICEST. R. Horseley and L. F. document.text: Since the death of Rev. Dr. Malcolm MacVicar the Virginia Union Univer sity, near Richmond, has been without a president. Information has just been received that the executive board of the American Baptist Home Mission Society, which controls the institution, held a meeting in New York, and ap pointed Dr. George Rice Hovey to fill the place temporarily. The prospects are that he will be made president permanently. Dr. Hovey has been connected with the university for some years. He is a man of exceptional ability. The Virginia Union Univer sity is situated just outside the north ern boundaries of Richmond.  It has a number of splendid buildings and is doing a great work for the colored race. J. W. Adcock, of Amherst county, who was employed in the Buena Vista furnace yard on the cinder dump, was, a few nights ago, run over by the cinder engine and both of his legs mashed. It is thought that he was asleep, as no one saw him when the accident took place. His left leg was amputated above the ankle and it is thought that the other one will also have to be taken off. While a freight train was engaged in shifting on the Atlantic Coast Line, in Manchester, a car loaded with lum ber weighing 30,000 pounds broke away, tore the track to pieces and rushed into - Perry street, narrowly missing a crowded street car and scattering pedestrians right and left. The car toppled over and strewed the street with lumber. The Neff-Rice Camp, Confederate Verterans, held their annual reunion near Newmarket. Lieut. Gov. Joseph Willard, of Fairfax, Hon. Henry Downing, of Warren, Col. E. E. Stick- ley and Mr. Gilbert Pence, of Shenan doah, delivered addresses. A numbet of camps and several thousand peo ple were present. Robert Lee, white, 30 years old and unmarried, who said his home was al Columbia, N. C., was arrested by Depu- .ty United States Marshal West at Lamberts Point on a charge of coun terfeiting. A number of spuriout coins were found in Lees possession 1 M rs. Mary A. Knick, aged 82 years, of Collierstown, Rockbridge county is dead. She was a daughter of Mr and Mrs. William Armentrout and re sided during her whole life in th house in which she was born and died. Her husband, William Knick, died from the effects of a wound which h received in the battle of Chancellors ville, in May, 1863. Three sons survive her. After spending seven months in th inaccessible mountains of Tazewell county in order to avoid the officer! of the law, Thomas K. Leedy, t wealthy farmer, rode into Tazewe! and surrendered to, the sheriff, whe met him by appointment at the horn of State Senator J. N. Harman, whe will act as his counsel. In Januarj last according to the charge, Leed shot and killed Walter Harris, a pas senger on a train, near Graham. H immediately took to the mountains and the officers found it impossible tc arrest him. Finally, however, Leedj grew tired of being a fugitive fronr justice and agreed to give himself up In addition to being charged with the killing of Harris, Leedys defendant in a suit for damages amounting tc 10,000 brought by the relatives 01 th dead man. His trial on the charge ol murder will take place next month It is thought that Leedy will be ac quitted. He is a man well-known ir the Southwest. He posses great phy sical strength and exceptional skill in the use of the revolver and rifle. A sensational horsewhipping occur red on the streets of Leesburg ir which Mayor S. Carroll Chancelloi played the role of victim. Mrs. Geo Ferguson, who had charged the mayo with slandering her, wielded the wea pon, and mayor in defending himsell struck Mrs. .Ferguson with his cane The community has been thrown intc a perfect fever of excitement in conse quence vof the affair. It seems that about a year ago the mayor boarded at the home of Mrs. Ferguson. Re cently anonymous letters have beer, circulated concerning his conduct, and the mayor accused Mrs. Ferguson ol being their author. Harry Hoover, a young blacksmith living in Basic City, and working ir Staunton, was run over by a C.  O train while on his way to work. H later died. One foot and one arm were cut off and he was badly cut about the head and body. He was.2 years of age and has a wife at Basic It is thought he was riding a freight and tried to jump off before reaching the station, when he fell under the train. The first case under the new drug law came up Thursday when a Rich mond druggist was fined 25 for the sale of cocaine to a victim of the co caine habit. The police justice an nounced that in the future the fine would be 100 for each offense. The last Legislature passed a law forbid ding the sale of cocaine to any per sons except physicians, dentists and druggists. In Richmond many of the victims of the drug are young boys. Rockbridge Chapter of Royal Arch Masons was organized at Lexington by Mr. William J. Hubard, of Lynch burg, assisted by Mr. J. W. C. Bryant and Mr. B  F. Grove, of Clifton Forge The following officers were elected- .High priest, R. E. Hutton king, V B. McClure scribe, H. O. Dold. There were twenty applcations presented for membership.

On Thursday after the first Monday in May, 1845, the first county court of the newly form ed county of Appomattox met a Clover Hjill, the new county seat. Among those meeting to organ ize the new countys government were Joel Watkins, William Math ews, Major Thomas Rudd, Joh W. Marshall, Dr. Rueben D. Pa mer, Col. Benj. P. Walker, Co Thomas H. Flood, Nathan L Hancock, Bryant Nowlin, Co. Z. E. Cheatham, Washingto Hunter, Sterling O. Andersoi John HL Plunkett and Jame. McDearmon. Joel Watkins, senior justice o the county w a s commissionec the first sheriff. Samuel D. Me Dearmon, William James Me Dearmon and William J. Wat kins were named deputies. Th. following other county officer were named All the first offi cers were named by the counts court instead of by election. John T. Bocock, first clerk Thomas S. Bocock, first com monwealths attorney  Thoma W. Johns, commissioner of reve nue Andrew B. Baker, corroner Before the next term of th court, John T. Bocock, the firs clerk, died and Henry F. Bocock his son, was named in his place He continued to hold this pos until July 1, 1860, when he re signed and moved to Lynchburj to engage in the mercantile bus iness. ! Col. Z. E. Cheatham, who hai been in the legislature iron Campbell county before the for mation of Appomattox, was th first representative of Appomat tox in the Hfciuse of Delegates He had also been  appoints county surveyor. The post offices in the count when it was formed were Clov er Hill, the county seat. Thi was soon afterwards changed t Appomattox Court House, nov Old Appomattox Bent Creek Oakville, Walkers Church Pamplin, then called Merrymlan Shop Ready Spring and Con cord, then kept at Chiltons Tav ern. document.text: APPOMATTOX COUNTY Historical Sketch The County took its name from the Appomattox River, L ajwaters of which are in this county. This in turn was ed after a tribe of Indians who inhabited its lower banks. Created by the 1844-1845 Session of the State Legislature, Act passed Feb, 8, 1845, which took effect May 1, 1845, mbraced parts of Buckingham, Prince Edward, Charlotte Campbell Counties, the general boundaries being set forth he Act, and subsequently was surveyed in the months of r June and July of that year by John Patteson, S. B. Co., ander Austin, Sur. Campbell Co., and Z. E. Cheatham, 1 had been appointed Surveyor of Appomattox County. It junded on the northwest by James River, and situated in the h central part of Virginia, and covers an area of 217,792 s, or approximately 340 square miles.
